ABESS algorithm: details

Jin Zhu, Yanhang Zhang

1/20/2022

Source: vignettes/v10-algorithm.Rmd
v10-algorithm.Rmd

Introduction

The ABESS algorithm employing ‚Äúsplicing‚Äù technique can exactly solve general best subset problem in a polynomial time. The aim of this page to provide a complete and coherent documentation for ABESS algorithm such that users can easily understand the ABESS algorithm and its variants, thereby facilitating the usage of abess software. We provide the details of splicing approach to linear model as follows, and its variants can be applied in similar ways.

Linear model

Sacrifices

Consider the ‚Ñì0\ell_{0} constraint minimization problem, minùõÉ‚Ñín(ùõÉ), s.t ‚à•ùõÉ‚à•0‚â§s, \min _{\boldsymbol{\beta}} \mathcal{L}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\beta}), \quad \text { s.t }\|\boldsymbol{\beta}\|_{0} \leq \mathrm{s}, where ${n}()=|y-X |{2}^{2}. $ Without loss of generality, we consider ‚à•ùõÉ‚à•0=s\|\boldsymbol{\beta}\|_{0}=\mathrm{s}. Given any initial set ùíú‚äÇùíÆ={1,2,‚Ä¶,p}\mathcal{A} \subset \mathcal{S}=\{1,2, \ldots, p\} with cardinality |ùíú|=s|\mathcal{A}|=s, denote ‚Ñê=ùíúc\mathcal{I}=\mathcal{A}^{\mathrm{c}} and compute ùõÉÃÇ=argminùõÉ‚Ñê=0‚Ñín(ùõÉ). \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\mathcal{I}}=0} \mathcal{L}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\beta}). We call ùíú\mathcal{A} and ‚Ñê\mathcal{I} as the active set and the inactive set, respectively.

Given the active set ùíú\mathcal{A} and ùõÉÃÇ\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, we can define the following two types of sacrifices:

  1. Backward sacrifice: For any j‚ààùíúj \in \mathcal{A}, the magnitude of discarding variable jj is, Œæj=‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÇùíú‚àñ{j})‚àí‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÇùíú)=Xj‚ä§Xj2n(ùõÉÃÇj)2, \xi_{j}=\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{\mathcal{A} \backslash\{j\}}\right)-\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{\mathcal{A}}\right)=\frac{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}{2 n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{j}\right)^{2},
  2. Forward sacrifice: For any j‚àà‚Ñêj \in \mathcal{I}, the magnitude of adding variable jj is, Œ∂j=‚Ñín(ùõÉùíúÃÇ)‚àí‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÇùíú+tÃÇ{j})=Xj‚ä§Xj2n(ùêùÃÇjXj‚ä§Xj/n)2. \zeta_{j}=\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}^{\mathcal{A}}}\right)-\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{\mathcal{A}}+\hat{t}^{\{j\}}\right)=\frac{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}{2 n}\left(\frac{\hat{\boldsymbol d}_{j}}{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j} / n}\right)^{2}. where tÃÇ=argmint‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÇùíú+t{j}),ùêùÃÇj=Xj‚ä§(y‚àíXùõÉÃÇ)/n\hat{t}=\arg \min _{t} \mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{\mathcal{A}}+t^{\{j\}}\right), \hat{\boldsymbol d}_{j}=X_{j}^{\top}(y-X \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) / n Intuitively, for j‚ààùíúj \in \mathcal{A} (or j‚àà‚Ñêj \in \mathcal{I} ), a large Œæj\xi_{j} (or Œ∂j\zeta_{j}) implies the jj th variable is potentially important.

Algorithm

Best-Subset Selection with a Given Support Size

Unfortunately, it is noteworthy that these two sacrifices are incomparable because they have different sizes of support set. However, if we exchange some ‚Äúirrelevant‚Äù variables in ùíú\mathcal{A} and some ‚Äúimportant‚Äù variables in ‚Ñê\mathcal{I}, it may result in a higher-quality solution. This intuition motivates our splicing method. Specifically, given any splicing size k‚â§sk \leq s, define

ùíúk={j‚ààùíú:‚àëi‚ààùíúI(Œæj‚â•Œæi)‚â§k} \mathcal{A}_{k}=\left\{j \in \mathcal{A}: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}} \mathrm{I}\left(\xi_{j} \geq \xi_{i}\right) \leq k\right\} to represent kk least relevant variables in ùíú\mathcal{A} and ‚Ñêk={j‚àà‚Ñê:‚àëi‚àà‚Ñê‚à£(Œ∂j‚â§Œ∂i)‚â§k} \mathcal{I}_{k}=\left\{j \in \mathcal{I}: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}} \mid\left(\zeta_{j} \leq \zeta_{i}\right) \leq k\right\} to represent kk most relevant variables in ‚Ñê.\mathcal{I} . Then, we splice ùíú\mathcal{A} and ‚Ñê\mathcal{I} by exchanging ùíúk\mathcal{A}_{k} and ‚Ñêk\mathcal{I}_{k} and obtain a new active set ùíúÃÉ=(ùíú‚àñùíúk)‚à™‚Ñêk. \tilde{\mathcal{A}}=\left(\mathcal{A} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{k}\right) \cup \mathcal{I}_{k}. Let ‚ÑêÃÉ=ùíúÃÉc,ùõÉÃÉ=argminùõÉ‚Ñê¬Ø=0‚Ñín(ùõÉ)\tilde{\mathcal{I}}=\tilde{\mathcal{A}}^{c}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\overline{\mathcal{I}}}=0} \mathcal{L}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\beta}), and œÑs>0\tau_{s}>0 be a threshold. If œÑs<\tau_{s}<‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÇ)‚àí‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÉ)\mathcal{L}_{n}(\hat{\boldsymbol\beta})-\mathcal{L}_{n}(\tilde{\boldsymbol\beta}), then AÃÉ\tilde{A} is preferable to ùíú.\mathcal{A} . The active set can be updated iteratively until the loss function cannot be improved by splicing. Once the algorithm recovers the true active set, we may splice some irrelevant variables, and then the loss function may decrease slightly. The threshold œÑs\tau_{s} can reduce this unnecessary calculation. Typically, œÑs\tau_{s} is relatively small, e.g.¬†œÑs=0.01slog(p)log(logn)/n.\tau_{s}=0.01 s \log (p) \log (\log n) / n.

Algorithm 1: BESS.Fix(s): Best-Subset Selection with a given support size s.
  1. Input: X,yX, y, positive integers kmax,mmaxk_{\max}, m_{\max}, and a threshold œÑs\tau_{s}.
  2. Initialize ùíú0={j:‚àëi=1pI(|Xj‚ä§yXj‚ä§Xj|‚â§|Xi‚ä§yXi‚ä§Xi|‚â§s},‚Ñê0=(ùíú0)c\mathcal{A}^{0}=\left\{j: \sum_{i=1}^{p} \mathrm{I}\left(\left|\frac{X_{j}^{\top} y}{\sqrt{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}}\right| \leq \left| \frac{X_{i}^{\top} y}{\sqrt{X_{i}^{\top} X_{i}}}\right| \leq \mathrm{s}\right\}, \mathcal{I}^{0}=\left(\mathcal{A}^{0}\right)^{c}\right., and (ùõÉ0,d0):\left(\boldsymbol\beta^{0}, d^{0}\right):

ùõÉ‚Ñê00=0,dùíú00=0,ùõÉùíú00=(ùêóùíú0‚ä§ùêóùíú0)‚àí1ùêóùíú0‚ä§ùê≤,d‚Ñê00=X‚Ñê0‚ä§(ùê≤‚àíùêóùõÉ0).\begin{align*} &\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\mathcal{I}^{0}}^{0}=0,\\ &d_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}^{0}=0,\\ &\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}^{0}=\left(\boldsymbol{X}_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}^{\top} \boldsymbol{X}_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{X}_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}^{\top} \boldsymbol{y},\\ &d_{\mathcal{I}^{0}}^{0}=X_{\mathcal{I}^{0}}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{X} \boldsymbol{\beta}^{0}\right). \end{align*}

  1. For m=0,1,‚Ä¶,mmaxm=0,1, \ldots, m_{\max}, do

    (ùõÉm+1,ùêùm+1,ùíúm+1,‚Ñêm+1)=Splicing(ùõÉm,ùêùm,ùíúm,‚Ñêm,kmax,œÑs).\left(\boldsymbol{\beta}^{m+1}, \boldsymbol{d}^{m+1}, \mathcal{A}^{m+1}, \mathcal{I}^{m+1}\right)= \text{Splicing} \left(\boldsymbol{\beta}^{m}, \boldsymbol{d}^{m}, \mathcal{A}^{m}, \mathcal{I}^{m}, k_{\max }, \tau_{s}\right).

    If (ùíúm+1,‚Ñêm+1)=(ùíúm,‚Ñêm)\left(\mathcal{A}^{m+1}, \mathcal{I}^{m+1}\right)=\left(\mathcal{A}^{m}, \mathcal{I}^{m}\right), then stop

    End For

  2. Output (ùõÉÃÇ,ùêùÃÇ,ùíúÃÇ,‚ÑêÃÇ)=(ùõÉm+1,ùêùm+1ùíúm+1,‚Ñêm+1).(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}, \hat{\mathcal{A}}, \hat{\mathcal{I}})=\left(\boldsymbol{\beta}^{m+1}, \boldsymbol{d}^{m+1} \mathcal{A}^{m+1}, \mathcal{I}^{m+1}\right).

Algorithm 2: Splicing (ùõÉ,d,ùíú,‚Ñê,kmax,œÑs)\left(\boldsymbol\beta, d, \mathcal{A}, \mathcal{I}, k_{\max }, \tau_{s}\right)

  1. Input: ùõÉ,ùêù,ùíú,‚Ñê,kmax\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{d}, \mathcal{A}, \mathcal{I}, k_{\max }, and œÑs.\tau_{\mathrm{s}} .

  2. Initialize L0=L=12n‚à•y‚àíXŒ≤‚à•22L_{0}=L=\frac{1}{2 n}\|y-X \beta\|_{2}^{2}, and set Œæj=Xj‚ä§Xj2n(Œ≤j)2,Œ∂j=Xj‚ä§Xj2n(djXj‚ä§Xj/n)2,j=1,‚Ä¶,p.\xi_{j}=\frac{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}{2 n}\left(\beta_{j}\right)^{2}, \zeta_{j}=\frac{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}{2 n}\left(\frac{d_{j}}{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j} / n}\right)^{2}, j=1, \ldots, p.

  3. For k=1,2,‚Ä¶,kmaxk=1,2, \ldots, k_{\max }, do

    ùíúk={j‚ààùíú:‚àëi‚ààùíúI(Œæj‚â•Œæi)‚â§k}\mathcal{A}_{k}=\left\{j \in \mathcal{A}: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}} \mathrm{I}\left(\xi_{j} \geq \xi_{i}\right) \leq k\right\}

    ‚Ñêk={j‚àà‚Ñê:‚àëi‚àà‚ÑêI(Œ∂j‚â§Œ∂i)‚â§k}\mathcal{I}_{k}=\left\{j \in \mathcal{I}: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}} \mathrm{I}\left(\zeta_{j} \leq \zeta_{i}\right) \leq k\right\}

    Let ùíúÃÉk=(ùíú‚àñùíúk)‚à™‚Ñêk,‚ÑêÃÉk=(‚Ñê‚àñ‚Ñêk)‚à™ùíúk\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{k}=\left(\mathcal{A} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{k}\right) \cup \mathcal{I}_{k}, \tilde{\mathcal{I}}_{k}=\left(\mathcal{I} \backslash \mathcal{I}_{k}\right) \cup \mathcal{A}_{k} and solve

    ùõÉÃÉùíúk=(ùêóùíúk‚ä§ùêóùíúk)‚àí1ùêóùíúk‚ä§y,ùõÉÃÉ‚Ñêk=0\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{{\mathcal{A}}_{k}}=\left(\boldsymbol{X}_{\mathcal{A}_{k}}^{\top} \boldsymbol{X}_{{\mathcal{A}}_{k}}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{X}_{{\mathcal{A}_{k}}}^{\top} y, \quad \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{{\mathcal{I}}_{k}}=0

    ùêùÃÉ‚Ñêk=X‚Ñêk‚ä§(y‚àíXŒ≤ÃÉ)/n,ùêùÃÉùíúk=0.\tilde{\boldsymbol d}_{\mathcal{I}^k}=X_{\mathcal{I}^k}^{\top}(y-X \tilde{\beta}) / n,\quad \tilde{\boldsymbol d}_{\mathcal{A}^k} = 0.

    Compute ‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÉ)=12n‚à•y‚àíXùõÉÃÉ‚à•22.\mathcal{L}_{n}(\tilde{\boldsymbol\beta})=\frac{1}{2 n}\|y-X \tilde{\boldsymbol\beta}\|_{2}^{2}.

    If L>‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÉ)L>\mathcal{L}_{n}(\tilde{\boldsymbol\beta}), then

    (ùõÉÃÇ,ùêùÃÇ,ùíúÃÇ,‚ÑêÃÇ)=(ùõÉÃÉ,ùêùÃÉ,ùíúÃÉk,‚ÑêÃÉk)(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}, \hat{\mathcal{A}}, \hat{\mathcal{I}})=\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{d}}, \tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{k}, \tilde{\mathcal{I}}_{k}\right)

    L=‚Ñín(ùõÉÃÉ).L=\mathcal{L}_{n}(\tilde{\boldsymbol\beta}).

    End for

  4. If L0‚àíL<œÑsL_{0}-L<\tau_{s}, then (ùõÉÃÇ,dÃÇ,AÃÇ,IÃÇ)=(ùõÉ,d,ùíú,‚Ñê).(\hat{\boldsymbol\beta}, \hat{d}, \hat{A}, \hat{I})=(\boldsymbol\beta, d, \mathcal{A}, \mathcal{I}).

  5. Output (ùõÉÃÇ,ùêùÃÇ,ùíúÃÇ,‚ÑêÃÇ)(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}, \hat{\mathcal{A}}, \hat{\mathcal{I}}).

Determining the Best Support Size with SIC

In practice, the support size is usually unknown. We use a data-driven procedure to determine s. For any active set ùíú\mathcal{A}, define an SIC\mathrm{SIC} as follows: SIC(ùíú)=nlog‚Ñíùíú+|ùíú|log(p)loglogn, \operatorname{SIC}(\mathcal{A})=n \log \mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{A}}+|\mathcal{A}| \log (p) \log \log n, where ‚Ñíùíú=minŒ≤‚Ñê=0‚Ñín(Œ≤),‚Ñê=(ùíú)c\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{A}}=\min _{\beta_{\mathcal{I}}=0} \mathcal{L}_{n}(\beta), \mathcal{I}=(\mathcal{A})^{c}. To identify the true model, the model complexity penalty is logp\log p and the slow diverging rate loglogn\log \log n is set to prevent underfitting. Theorem 4 states that the following ABESS algorithm selects the true support size via SIC.

Let smaxs_{\max } be the maximum support size. We suggest smax=o(nlogp)s_{\max }=o\left(\frac{n}{\log p}\right) as the maximum possible recovery size. Typically, we set smax=[nlog(p)loglogn]s_{\max }=\left[\frac{n}{\log (p) \log \log n}\right] where [x][x] denotes the integer part of xx.

Algorithm 3: ABESS.

  1. Input: X,yX, y, and the maximum support size smax.s_{\max } .

  2. For s=1,2,‚Ä¶,smaxs=1,2, \ldots, s_{\max }, do

    (ùõÉÃÇs,ùêùÃÇs,ùíúÃÇs,‚ÑêÃÇs)=BESS.Fixed(s).\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{s}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}_{s}, \hat{\mathcal{A}}_{s}, \hat{\mathcal{I}}_{s}\right)= \text{BESS.Fixed}(s).

    End for

  3. Compute the minimum of SIC:

    smin=argminsSIC(ùíúÃÇs).s_{\min }=\arg \min _{s} \operatorname{SIC}\left(\hat{\mathcal{A}}_{s}\right).

  4. Output (ùõÉÃÇsmin,ùêùÃÇsmin,AÃÇsmin,‚ÑêÃÇsmin).\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{s_{\operatorname{min}}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}_{s_{\min }}, \hat{A}_{s_{\min }}, \hat{\mathcal{I}}_{s_{\min }}\right) .

The corresponding notations in abess() function

Notations in algorithm Parameters in ùöäùöãùöéùöúùöú\mathtt{abess} Definitions
mmaxm_{\max} max.splicing.iter The maximum number of splicing algorithm
kmaxk_{\max} c.max The maximum splicing size
1,‚Ä¶,smax1,\ldots,s_{\max} support.size A sequence representing the support sizes
SIC\operatorname{SIC} tune.type The type of criterion for choosing the support size
{G1,‚Ä¶,GJ}\{G_1, \ldots, G_J\} group.index A vector indicator the group that each variable belongs to
Œª\lambda lambda A value for regularized best subset selection
Golden-section searching gs.range Upper and lower bounds of the search range
